items.title: Hurricane Cost City at Least $154 Million in Overtime
items.abstract: Eighty-one percent of the total went to the Police and Sanitation Departments alone, according to a report released Friday by the Independent Budget Office.

items.title: City Prepares for a Strike, Maybe This Week, by School Bus Drivers
items.abstract: Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott outlined contingency plans as a union leader urged negotiations on job security, the main issue.

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: City Officials Say School Bus Strike Would Be Irresponsible
items.abstract: Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott said a strike by New York City school bus drivers, which could affect as many as 152,000 public and private school students, was “irresponsible and disrespectful.”

items.title: City’s Delayed Traffic Study to Guide Regulation of Uber Vehicles
items.abstract: The study, which was originally due at the end of November, aimed to assess the ride-hailing service’s effects on traffic congestion in Manhattan.

items.title: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
items.abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.

items.title: Open Subway Cars May Come to New York City as Early as 2020
items.abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority could award a contract as early as next year to build 10 of them, officials said, bringing to life an idea that has been debated for years.

items.title: New York City Takes Steps to Better Fight Suits Against Police
items.abstract: The Police Department has created a 40-member legal unit to uncover evidence to fight lawsuits, and the city’s Law Department has hired 30 lawyers to try more cases in court.

items.title: Mayor de Blasio Lays Out Vision for New York in State of the City Address
items.abstract: The mayor adapted his liberal ambitions to a broad range of projects aimed at the everyday dangers and inconveniences of New York City life.

items.title: Traffic Deaths in New York City Drop to 200, a Record Low
items.abstract: Fewer people were killed last year in vehicle crashes, a sign that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Vision Zero plan is working. But pedestrian deaths increased.

items.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
items.abstract: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: New York City’s Poor Were Promised Half-Priced MetroCards. They’re Still Waiting.
items.abstract: New York City was scheduled to start a discount fare program for low-income riders on Jan. 1. But the rollout has been a bit of a mess.
keywords: Community Service Society of New York

items.title: Of 800,000 Poor New Yorkers, Only 30,000 Can Get the New Half-Priced MetroCards
items.abstract: The city’s new Fair Fares program will get off to a modest start, with only those receiving cash assistance from the city eligible for the discounts.

items.title: City Schools Are ‘Staying Open,’ Mayor Eric Adams Says
items.abstract: But the spike in Omicron cases has created trepidation for many parents.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.

items.title: Noncitizens’ Right to Vote Becomes Law in New York City
items.abstract: Starting next year, 800,000 legal permanent residents will be eligible to vote in municipal elections.
keywords: Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)

items.title: America’s Most Energy Efficient Cities
items.abstract: A new report by the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy can help you gauge just how green your city is — or wants to be.

items.title: Mayor Adams Promotes ‘Radically Practical’ Agenda in Washington
items.abstract: Eric Adams spoke at a national gathering of mayors and focused on the importance of cities demonstrating that government can work.
